summary.para: Represents a code page in the sense of a object, using a mechanism that allows basic manipulations on a system where support for the code page may not be installed.
Normally the Codepage object is constructed from an Encoding object, but for persistence it can be constructed from a string.

If the code page is supported by the local machine you can use the property to retrieve the corresponding .NET encoding object. If you access this property for a code page that is not supported on this machine this will result in a .

Using this mechanism as opposed to directly using the Encoding class means that we can still work with files for which a code page is not supported on a certain machine (at least as long as no code page conversion operations are needed). This may be a common use case when a file is converted on one system and then edited on another.
Use the and properties to determine if the codepage has been set and if it is supported on this system.

Construction from a code page name.
See the property for information about what is considered to be a valid code page name.

remarks.para: This constructor is typically used only in (de-)serialization. If possible a new code page object should be created from an existing encoding object instead.

member.summary: Constructs an invalid code page object (does not set a code page name).

member.summary: Create a deep clone of the other object.

member.name: P:Sdl.Core.Globalization.Codepage.IsValid
member.summary: True if a code page name has been set.
member.remarks: This does not mean that the actual code page string is valid. Since the code page name could represent a code page that is not supported on this particular system there is no safe way we can determine if the name is a valid encoding name or not. Thus anything else than null or an empty string for a name must be considered a "valid" code page name. To test if a codepage is supported on this system, use the property.

member.name: P:Sdl.Core.Globalization.Codepage.IsSupported
member.summary: True if the code page is supported on this system.

member.name: P:Sdl.Core.Globalization.Codepage.Name
member.summary: The IANA preferred name of the code page, e.g. windows-1252 or iso-8859-1.
member.remarks: This corresponds to the Encoding.WebName property for code pages supported by the machine.

member.name: P:Sdl.Core.Globalization.Codepage.Encoding
member.summary:
Returns the .NET Encoding that corresponds to this code page.
If the code page is null this property returns null.
If the encoding is not supported on this system an is thrown.

summary.para: Represents a language in the sense of a object, using a mechanism that allows basic manipulations on a system where the language is not fully supported.

The reason we use this type as opposed to the CultureInfo class in the .NET Framework is that when working with files we may convert the file on a system that supports a particular language (i.e. the CultureInfo for this language abbreviation is known), but the file may subsequently be opened on a system that does not yet have support for this language.

Depending on what processing is to be done this may be a perfectly valid use case, and it would be too harsh a restriction to require support for the language to be installed on all systems that may ever look at the file.
Under normal circumstances the language should be created from a CultureInfo object.

In addition this wrapper allows a language to be represented by a plain string when no CultureInfo for this language is supported on the system, and thus allows the language to be represented until some truly language specific processing is needed (i.e. when the corresponding CultureInfo is required).
When supported by the operating system the corresponding CultureInfo can be obtained directly from the property. If not supported this will throw an .
Use the and properties to determine if the language has been set and whether it is supported by the operating system.

member.name: P:Sdl.Core.Globalization.Language.DefaultDisplaySettings
member.summary: Default settings for how languages should be shown to users.

remarks.para: Since this is a static property, changing its values means changing the language display for the entire process.
If you are interested to know when these properties change, attach a handler to the event of this object.

member.name: T:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacySdlxLanguage
member.summary: Used to find CultureInfo and LCID values from a given SDLX 'iso' code.

member.name: F:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacySdlxLanguage.SdlxCultureMap
member.summary: Maps predefined SDLX to CultureInfo codes and those that are added when found to be the same as the TRADOS ISO codes.

member.name: F:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacySdlxLanguage.SdlxIsoToTradosIso
member.summary: Maps SDLX to TRADOS codes where they are different.

member.name: F:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacySdlxLanguage.SdlxIsoToTradosIsoValues
member.summary: List of SDLX to TRADOS in pairs.

member.name: F:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacySdlxLanguage.SdlxCultureMapValues
member.summary: List of initial SDLX ISO codes to .NET CultureInfo names

member.name: M:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacySdlxLanguage.GetLcidFromIsoCode(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a LCID from the given SDLX 'iso' code.
member.param: The SDLX 'iso' code which may be specific to SDLX for some languages.
member.returns: An LCID for the SDLX language code if supported.

member.name: M:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacySdlxLanguage.GetCultureInfoFromIsoCode(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a CultureInfo from the given SDLX 'iso' code.
member.param: The SDLX 'iso' code which may be specific to SDLX for some languages.
member.returns: An CultureInfo for the SDLX language code if supported.

member.name: T:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage
member.summary: Represents a project language in the client object model

member.name: M:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage.IsInstalledLcid(System.Int32)
member.summary: true if the specified LCID is supported by this operating system installation.

remarks.para: The implementation calls IsValidLocale on the Win32 API.
Note that this returns false for proprietary TRADOS "LCID" values.

member.param: Locale identifier of the locale to validate
member.returns: true if the specified LCID is supported by this operating system installation.

member.name: M:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage.IsProprietaryLcid(System.Int32)
member.summary: true if the LCID is one of the TRADOS proprietary "LCID" values.
member.param: Locale identifier of the locale to validate
member.returns: true if the LCID is one of the TRADOS proprietary "LCID" values.

member.name: M:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Construction from a 2 or 5 letter ISO code (i.e. with or without sublanguage/region). The 2 letter language code should be separated from the 2 letter country code with a dash. Examples: EN-US, DE-DE, SW-SE, JP

member.name: M:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Construction from an LCID value. The LCID can be a valid Windows/.NET supported LCID, or a TRADOS defined "LCID", such as 2108 for Gaelic (Scotland).
member.param: Locale identifier of the locale to validate

member.name: M:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: Compares two Language objects. If they are both valid and have the same LCID they are considered equal. If they are not valid they are considered equal if they have the same "ISO code".
member.returns: true if they are both of type LegacyTradosLanguage with the same Lcid and IsoCode

member.name: M:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage.GetHashCode
member.summary: Returns a hash code value for the Language object.
member.returns: A hash code value for the Language object.

member.name: M:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage.ToString
member.summary: Returns a representing the Language object.
member.returns: A representing the Language object.

member.name: P:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage.IsValid
member.summary: true if the language is a valid LCID and ISO language code.

member.name: P:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage.IsInstalled
member.summary: true if the language with this LCID is supported directly by the operating system.

member.name: P:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage.IsProprietary
member.summary: true if this LCID is a proprietary TRADOS "LCID".

member.name: P:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage.IsoCode
member.summary:
The 5 letter ISO code corresponding to this language, in this format: EN-US, JP-JP, etc.
May be empty if IsValid is false.

member.name: M:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage.GetLocaleInfo(Sdl.Core.Globalization.LanguageFormat,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Retrieves the locale info.
member.param: An enum specifying whether to return the language info as English, Native or ISO form.
A boolean specifying whether to mention the region in the return string.
member.returns: A string describing the Locale id.

member.name: M:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage.GetLocaleInfo(System.Int32,Sdl.Core.Globalization.LanguageFormat,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Retrieves the locale info.
member.param: An enum specifying whether to return the language info as English, Native or ISO form.
A boolean specifying whether to mention the region in the return string.
member.returns: A string describing the Locale id.

member.name: P:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage.Lcid
member.summary:
The Windows/.NET LCID for the language.
May be 0 if is false.

member.name: M:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage.GetAllLcids
member.summary: Get all the possible Trados LCIDs from languages/locations known to TRADOS.
member.returns: An array of LCIDs

member.name: M:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LegacyTradosLanguage.GetLcidFromIsoCode(System.String)

member.name: T:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LocalizableString
member.summary: Data type used for strings in Spring configuration files that may need to be localized.

remarks.para: If this object is constructed from a plain text string it works like a normal System.String.

To reference a resource ID, create this object from a resource identifier string, in the following format: resource://[AssemblyPath\AssemblyName]/[resource ID], where [AssemblyPath\AssemblyName] is the name of the base assembly (with optional path) that the string resource is located in and [resource ID] is the ID of the string resource from which the localized string should be loaded.
The ResourceManager is used to load the string from the assembly, so a localized version of the string (depending on the current thread locale) should be returned if available.

member.name: M:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LocalizableString.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Create from a literal string or resource identifier.

remarks.para: If the content starts with "assembly://" it is deemed to be a resource identifier.

Resource identifiers use the following format: assembly://[AssemblyPath\AssemblyName]/[resource ID], where [AssemblyPath\AssemblyName] is the name of the base assembly that the string resource is located in (with an optional path, specify this only for assemblies not located in the default application folder) and [resource ID] is the ID of the string resource from which the localized string should be loaded.

member.param: the literal string to use in the construction

member.name: M:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LocalizableString.ToString
member.summary: Returns the localized text this string represents.
member.returns: The localized text this string represents.

member.name: P:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LocalizableString.Content
member.summary: Returns the localized text this string represents.
member.remarks: Throws exceptions if using a resource ID and the assembly or string cannot be loaded.

member.name: P:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LocalizableString.RawContent
member.summary: Returns the string or resource ID this localizable string uses to get the localized text.

member.name: P:Sdl.Core.Globalization.LocalizableString.IsResource
member.summary: true if the localizable text is retrieved from an assembly.
